summary: Email from an Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York correcting the date on Ghislaine Maxwell's arrest warrant and requesting Judge Smith to sign the corrected version. The email indicates an administrative error in the original warrant's date.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The individual whose arrest warrant is being corrected and signed; central figure in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Judge Smith
persons.context: The judge being asked to sign the corrected arrest warrant for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The sender of the email, working in the Southern District of New York, who is correcting the date on Maxwell's arrest warrant and requesting the judge's signature.

connections.description: Prosecutor requesting judge to sign a corrected arrest warrant in an official capacity.
Prosecutor handling the arrest warrant for Maxwell, indicating involvement in her prosecution.
Judge being asked to sign the arrest warrant for Maxwell, indicating judicial oversight of her case.

events.title: Correction of Maxwell Arrest Warrant
events.description: Assistant United States Attorney sends email to correct the date on Ghislaine Maxwell's arrest warrant and requests Judge Smith to sign the corrected version.

keyFacts: An arrest warrant for Ghislaine Maxwell was issued, but it initially had an incorrect date (wrong year).
An Assistant United States Attorney in the Southern District of New York sent a corrected version of the warrant on June 29, 2020, requesting Judge Smith to sign it.
The email indicates procedural steps in the legal process leading to Maxwell's arrest and prosecution.
